column7: key_holding
column9: practical_takeaway

column2: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India
column7: Right to silence is part of right to life (Art 21). Confessions obtained by coercion are inadmissible.
column9: You have the right to remain silent. Never confess under pressure.

column2: D.K. Basu v. State of West Bengal
column7: Custodial interrogation rules. Police must inform of right to medical exam and right to inform relative.
column9: Police must follow specific procedures during custody. Violation = grounds to suppress confession.

column7: Narco analysis polygraph test and brain imaging without consent = violation of Art 20(3). Inadmissible in evidence.
column9: Police cannot force you into medical tests. Any confession from such tests is invalid in court.

column2: Jaswinder Singh v. State of Punjab
column7: Bail is rule jail is exception. Presumption of innocence is fundamental.
column9: You have strong rights to bail even if arrested. Don't believe 'no bail possible' claims.

column7: Police liability for wrongful arrest. Victim can claim damages under tort law.
column9: If arrested wrongfully you can later sue police for compensation.

column7: Police excess and abuse of authority = criminal liability for police officers.
column9: Police officers can be personally prosecuted for misconduct. It's not just the 'system'.

column2: Romesh Thappar v. State of Madras
column7: Freedom of movement is fundamental right (Art 19). Arrest requires specific legal basis.
column9: Police cannot arrest just on suspicion. They need specific legal reasons.

column7: Bail conditions cannot be unreasonable or oppressive. Court must consider financial capacity.
column9: Don't accept impossible bail conditions. Demand reasonable bail.

column2: Ram Kumar v. State of Delhi
column7: State liable for compensation for unlawful arrest and wrongful prosecution.
column9: Wrongful arrest = civil liability. You can claim damages in court.

column2: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar
column7: Police cannot arrest for bailable offences without following procedure. Mandatory guidelines.
column9: For minor crimes police cannot just arrest. They must follow specific rules.

column2: Mihir Rajesh Shah v. State of Maharashtra
column7: Every person arrested in India must be informed of grounds of arrest in writing in language they understand. Constitutional mandate in ALL offences.
column9: Demand WRITTEN grounds of arrest immediately in your language. If refused demand magistrate inspection.

column2: Vihaan Kumar v. State of Haryana
column7: Failure to inform about grounds of arrest violates fundamental rights under Article 22(1). No credible information = no valid arrest.
column9: Police must have CREDIBLE information before arrest. Bald suspicion is not enough.

column2: Prabir Purkayastha v. State (NCT of Delhi)
column7: Violation of Article 22(1) vitiates the arrest process. Failure to communicate grounds renders arrest illegal.
column9: Breach of Article 22(1) = grounds to challenge entire arrest and detention.

column2: Union of India v. Man Singh Verma
column7: High Courts can grant compensation for wrongful detention where person was unlawfully confined.
column9: Unlawful detention lasting months can result in monetary compensation from state.

column2: Edwin Thomas v. State of Karnataka
column7: Procedural irregularities in arrest do not automatically grant bail. But grave violations like denial of legal counsel do render arrest illegal.
column9: Minor procedural lapses ≠ bail. But major violations like denied lawyer = grounds for release.

column2: Radhika Agarwal v. Union of India
column7: Minor procedural lapses by officers should not be magnified by courts. Burden of proof on person challenging arrest in special statutes.
column9: In PMLA/UAPA arrests procedural lapses are easier to challenge. Document everything.

column7: Non-compliance with Section 41 or 41A CrPC = entitlement to bail. Procedural safeguards are facets of Article 21.
column9: Any arrest violating Sec 41/41A automatically gives you ground for bail.

column2: Directorate of Enforcement v. Subhash Sharma
column7: Arrest carried out in flagrant disregard of procedural requirements = grounds for bail. Denial of legal counsel = serious breach.
column9: Enforcement agencies must follow procedure. Breach of legal rights = automatic bail.

column2: Hussainara Khatoon v. State of Bihar
column7: Object of bail bond is only to ensure accused doesn't flee or hide. Not punitive in nature.
column9: Bail is about ensuring appearance in court. It's NOT punishment. Demand reasonable conditions.

column2: Harinarayan Rajbhar v. State of Uttar Pradesh
column7: Bail granted to former MP despite serious charges based on presumption of innocence and other bail considerations.
column9: High status or position ≠ grounds for jail. Bail should be based on case merits.

column2: Yogesh Sharma v. State of Haryana
column7: False cases lodged with malice = damages payable by state. Police cannot lodge cases out of vendetta.
column9: If police registers false case from vendetta sue them for damages.

column2: Arun Kumar Jindal v. Central Bureau of Investigation
column7: When trap proceedings uncover further information about offences CBI can proceed with further investigation. Nature and gravity matter.
column9: CBI can investigate further crimes discovered during initial investigation. Scope is not limited.

column7: Conviction under POCSO Act upheld where sexual assault on child was proven beyond doubt. 20 years rigorous imprisonment.
column9: Child sexual abuse = serious crime. Conviction requires solid evidence from court.

column2: Puja Khedkar v. State of Maharashtra
column7: Anticipatory bail granted to IAS probationer despite false document charges based on cooperation and presumption of innocence.
column9: Bail is available even for serious crimes if you cooperate and have no criminal history.

column2: Rajesh Chaddha v. State of U.P.
column7: Mere repetition of IO statements in court without concrete evidence insufficient for conviction under Sec 498A. Acquittal restored.
column9: Domestic violence charges need REAL evidence not just police statements. Repetition ≠ proof.

column2: D. Balasubramaniam v. State of Tamil Nadu
column7: Court dismissed petition under Sec 482 where chargesheet filed under Sec 306 (abetment to suicide). Procedural requirements met.
column9: Abetment charges require specific evidence linking person to suicide. Investigation must be thorough.

column7: Reversal of acquittal improper when based on mere surmises conjectures and IO testimony repeating Sec 161 statements.
column9: Murder conviction cannot be based on investigators just repeating their notes. Need independent evidence.

column2: Vile Parle Police Station v. Jayprakash Sru Shetty
column7: Anticipatory bail application filed under BNSS 2023 for alleged criminal intimidation and wrongful constraint.
column9: Anticipatory bail available in Bombay HC for intimidation charges if credible threat of arrest exists.

column7: Separate orders required under Sec 446 CrPC: first for cancellation of bail bonds then for imposing penalty. Single order invalid.
column9: Trial court must pass TWO separate orders: one for bail cancellation one for penalty. Procedural requirement.

column2: Madhya Pradesh High Court (Sexual Assault Case)
column7: Conviction under Sec 366 376(2)(g) 342 maintained. Conviction under SC/ST Atrocities Act set aside. Sentence reduced to 10 years RI.
column9: Sexual assault on kidnapped woman convicted. SC/ST Act conviction needs separate proof of caste angle.

column7: Supreme Court directed Jharkhand HC to pronounce judgments in pending Criminal Appeals within prescribed timelines.
column9: Judgment delays = violation of right to speedy trial. SC can direct HC to expedite.

column7: Mother convicted of killing two minor daughters under Sec 302. Supreme Court partly allowed appeal reducing conviction.
column9: Murder of minors by parent = serious crime. Mental health circumstances considered in sentencing.

column7: HC directed state to issue guidelines preventing IOs from copy-pasting statements even in serious offences. Recording statements must be proper.
column9: IOs copy-pasting statements in serious cases = malpractice. State must issue guidelines for proper recording.

column7: Confessions obtained through coercion duress or illegal interrogation suppressed under Sec 24-25 Indian Evidence Act.
column9: Confessions made under police pressure = automatically invalid. Court will exclude them.

column7: NDPS arrest based on test results. Lab confirmation determines guilt. Custody based on positive test results.
column9: NDPS charges require lab confirmation. Initial positive test = basis for custody pending confirmation.

column7: Forgery and cheating case. Evidence of deception and false documents must be clearly shown.
column9: Forgery conviction needs proof of false document and mens rea (intent to deceive).

column7: Criminal intimidation case. Statements and evidence of threats must be documented to show criminal intent.
column9: Criminal intimidation = making threats of injury. Evidence of threat communication essential.

column7: Landmark ruling reaffirming: Bail is rule jail is exception. Presumption of innocence is fundamental right.
column9: Every person has right to bail except in rarest of rare cases. Conviction must come AFTER trial not before.

column7: Custodial death of person under police custody = state liability. Compensation awarded for illegal detention and death.
column9: Death in police custody = automatic liability on state. Compensation will be awarded.

column7: False FIR lodged with malice = damages and damages for mental harassment of innocent person.
column9: False FIR = you can sue police for damages AND mental harassment compensation.

column7: Police torture during interrogation documented through medical exam = grounds for FIR against police and suppression of confession.
column9: Physical torture = FIR against police + confession suppressed. Medical exam = proof.

column7: High Court can modify unreasonable bail conditions set by trial court. Conditions must be proportionate to offence.
column9: Impossible bail conditions (e.g. ₹50L for theft) = HC will modify them to reasonable amounts.

column7: Police attempt to tamper with witness = ground for bail and separate FIR against police.
column9: Police threatening/bribing witnesses = FIR against them + grounds for bail for main accused.

column7: Person falsely implicated by police in fabricated case = damages and criminal prosecution of police.
column9: Falsely implicated in criminal case = sue police for damages + get FIR filed against them.

column7: Conviction set aside where prosecution failed to prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt. Acquittal reinstated.
column9: Prosecution MUST prove case beyond reasonable doubt. Suspicion ≠ conviction.

column7: Police extortion during investigation = Sec 170 BNS (Bribery) and Sec 172 BNS (Extortion). Criminal prosecution of officer.
column9: Police demanding money = FIR under Sec 170 BNS. Report to CBI or Anti-Corruption Bureau.

column7: Police arrest without warrant for non-cognizable offence = illegal. Bail automatic on this ground alone.
column9: Non-cognizable crime = police CANNOT arrest without magistrate order. Demand bail immediately.

column7: HC reviewing bail denial = must consider gravity of charge AND possibility of conviction AND presumption of innocence.
column9: When reviewing bail denial court MUST weigh: charge gravity + conviction probability + your presumption of innocence.

column7: Police refusing medical exam after arrest = violation of Sec 54 BNS. Demand magistrate to order examination.
column9: Police refusing medical exam = demand magistrate inspection immediately. Document all injuries with photos.

column7: Remand beyond 15 days = exceptional circumstance requiring specific court order and justification.
column9: Police remand max 15 days (60 days total custody). After that demand magistrate hearing immediately.

column7: Wrongful arrest for 3 months without prima facie case = compensation of ₹2
column9: 000 awarded.
column11: Wrongful arrest for months = expect ₹2-5 lakh compensation from state.

column7: Even in special laws (UAPA) procedural safeguards of Art 22(1) apply. Written grounds of arrest mandatory.
column9: Even UAPA arrests need WRITTEN grounds. No verbal-only arrests permissible.

column7: Bail conditions modified when accused cannot afford sureties. Court considered poor financial status.
column9: If you're poor and can't afford sureties court MUST modify bail conditions. Tell court your financial situation.

column7: Confessional statement made voluntarily before magistrate = admissible only if voluntary (Sec 26 IEA).
column9: Confession to magistrate admissible only if TRULY voluntary. Any duress/coercion = inadmissible.

column7: Bail in POCSO case rare but possible if no credible evidence. Presumption of innocence applies.
column9: POCSO charges can get bail if evidence weak. But this is rare. Evidence of child abuse = jail.

column7: SC/ST Atrocities Act: need to prove caste angle separately. Commission of offence + caste motive both necessary.
column9: Atrocities Act conviction needs: (1) Crime proved (2) Caste angle proved. Both required.

column7: Default bail under Sec 167(2) = absolute and indefeasible right if IO doesn't file chargesheet in time.
column9: If police don't file chargesheet within 90 days (or 180 for serious crimes) you get automatic bail.

column7: Person falsely implicated in criminal case by police malice = suit for damages under tort law against police department.
column9: Falsely implicated = sue police department for damages (typically ₹1-5 lakh).

column7: Anticipatory bail available in bailable offences where credible threat of arrest exists and FIR appears imminent.
column9: If credible threat of arrest anticipatory bail available BEFORE arrest. File immediately before FIR.

column7: Police must follow Sec 41/41A CrPC before arrest. Non-compliance = automatic bail on this ground alone.
column9: Before arrest police must: (1) Try to obtain police bail consent (2) Inform magistrate. Non-compliance = auto bail.

column7: Police remand limited to 15 days in any 60-day period. Excess remand = illegal detention.
column9: Max 15 days police remand per 60 days custody. After 15 days demand appearance before magistrate.

column7: Police detaining person without producing before magistrate = Sec 330 BNS (Wrongful Confinement). Criminal liability on officer.
column9: Not produced before magistrate within 24 hours = illegal. Police officer criminally liable. File FIR against them.

column7: Bail consideration for women: gender-specific protections and considerations apply. Courts consider safety and welfare.
column9: Women get gender-specific bail protections. Courts consider safety from harassment in bail conditions.

column7: Police denying lawyer access during interrogation = violation of Sec 50 BNS. Confession obtained = inadmissible.
column9: Police MUST allow you lawyer access within 3 hours of arrest (or immediately if serious crime). Denial = confession invalid.

column7: Police interrogation must be at police station by authorized officer. Home interrogation = improper procedure.
column9: Police can interrogate only at police station (or authorized place) by authorized officer. NOT at your home.

column7: Wife falsely accusing husband = husband can sue wife for defamation and false implication if charges dismissed.
column9: False accusation (like false DV case) = you can sue accuser for defamation and damages.

column7: Delhi HC grants anticipatory bail in cases where FIR not yet filed but threat is imminent and credible.
column9: Delhi HC is liberal with anticipatory bail. File immediately on credible threat of arrest.

column7: Maximum cumulative custody in non-serious crimes = 60 days (15 police + 90 days on extension for investigation).
column9: In regular crimes max 90 days custody total. In serious crimes max 6 months. After that release automatic.

column7: Chargesheet must be filed within 90 days of arrest (or 60 days for serious crimes). Delay = automatic bail.
column9: Chargesheet delay = you get automatic release (default bail). No need to apply.

column7: Witness statements must be recorded properly under Sec 161 BNS by authorized officer. Improper recording = evidence weak.
column9: Police witness statements must be detailed. Just note numbers = weak evidence.

column7: FIR must accurately describe offence. Vague FIR = ground to challenge investigation and get bail.
column9: If FIR is vague or factually incorrect you can challenge it and get bail.

column7: POCSO investigations must be thorough. Lack of evidence beyond child statement = acquittal risk.
column9: POCSO conviction needs corroborating evidence beyond child's statement. Medical/witness evidence helps.

column7: Chargesheet with defects (incomplete charges vague allegations) = ground to challenge and quash.
column9: Defective chargesheet = you can file petition to quash under Sec 482 CrPC.

column7: Bail conditions can be modified if they become impossible to comply with. Petition to modify always available.
column9: Bail conditions too harsh? Petition to modify. Court will reconsider based on circumstances.

column7: Investigation extensions beyond 90 days only in serious crimes with specific justification. Blanket extensions not allowed.
column9: Investigation extension allowed only in serious crimes with magistrate approval. Regular crimes = 90 day limit.

column7: Himachal HC grants anticipatory bail in private complaint cases where police may arrest without proper investigation.
column9: In Himachal private cases anticipatory bail is available on credible threat of police arrest.

column7: Trial court refusing to hear bail application = grounds for petition to HC. Every bail application must be heard.
column9: Even trial court refusal to hear bail = go to HC. Every application must be heard (not dismissed summarily).

column7: PMLA arrest requires specific credible information. Mere suspicion = no arrest. Bail available if credible info lacking.
column9: PMLA arrests need credible information about money laundering. Suspicion alone insufficient.

column7: SC/ST Atrocities bail is strict. But if evidence of false caste angle claim bail is available.
column9: Atrocities Act: bail hard BUT if false caste angle proved you can get bail.

column7: Confession to police under coercion = Sec 25 IEA (inadmissible). Must be to magistrate to be admissible.
column9: Confession to police officer = always inadmissible (Sec 25 IEA). Only magistrate confession counts.

column7: Every day of police remand must be justified with specific reasons. Blanket remands not allowed.
column9: Each remand day needs specific justification. Magistrate cannot grant remand without reasons.

column7: Women in custody must be under lady constable supervision. Violations = Sec 330 BNS (wrongful confinement).
column9: Women's custody = female constable must be present. Male-only interrogation = illegal.

column7: Matrimonial cases: DV acts used as tool for false implication. Court scrutinizes evidence carefully.
column9: In domestic cases courts check evidence carefully for false DV claims. Acquittal common if evidence weak.

column7: Dalit woman victim: enhanced protections in investigation. Witness intimidation = separate criminal charges.
column9: Dalit woman victims get enhanced protections. Intimidation of victim = separate crime against officer.

column7: Atrocities Act conviction needs proof caste angle was primary motive. Secondary angle = conviction risky.
column9: In Atrocities conviction caste must be PRIMARY motive not secondary. Burden on prosecution.

column7: Documented police brutality = FIR against officer under Sec 330-335 BNS. Compensation also available.
column9: Police brutality = FIR against officer + compensation claim. Medical exam = proof.

column7: Detention without warrant in home = Sec 330 BNS (Wrongful Confinement). Police must produce before magistrate.
column9: Detained at home without warrant = Sec 330 BNS against police. Only magistrate can order detention.

column7: Bail consent can be withdrawn any time by complainant. But bail already granted continues till formal modification.
column9: Accused bail consent given then withdrawn? Bail continues. Formal HC petition needed to cancel.

column7: Investigation report must be submitted in sealed cover to magistrate for extension approval. Disclosure to accused prohibited till later.
column9: Police investigation report kept sealed from accused. Disclosed only at trial. Helps prevent tampering.

column7: Rape cases: bail rare unless evidence very weak or false complaint credible. Burden on accused high.
column9: Rape case bail is HARD. Accused must show: (1) Weak evidence (2) False complaint credible. Very high burden.

column7: Witness threatened? Court can order protection under Sec 330 CrPC (now BNSS). Hiding witness = contempt.
column9: Witness threatened by accused/police? Court orders protection (relocation guards etc).

column7: Sexual assault case: medical evidence (FSL report) critical. Absence of medical evidence = acquittal likely.
column9: Sexual assault: medical exam CRITICAL. Delayed medical = evidence lost. Get exam within 72 hours.

column7: Circumstantial evidence conviction allowed ONLY when chain is complete. Single missing link = acquittal.
column9: Circumstantial cases: prosecution must prove COMPLETE chain. One broken link = acquittal mandatory.

column7: Youth first-time offender: bail favorable for rehabilitation. Court considers age and circumstances.
column9: First-time young offender? Bail likely. Courts favor rehabilitation over punishment for youth.

column7: Coastal town cases: anticipatory bail available for false implication threats where police cooperation unclear.
column9: Anticipatory bail in Karnataka coastal areas available on credible arrest threat.

column7: Property disputes: criminal case filed with FIR even when civil remedy available. Bail available if criminal element unclear.
column9: Property dispute criminalized? Check if ACTUAL criminal element or civil dispute. Bail easier if civil.

column7: Extortion claims require specific evidence of demand and threat. Bare assertion insufficient.
column9: Extortion claim needs: (1) Demand (2) Threat (3) Intention for wrongful gain. All three required.

column7: Bail for mentally ill person: court considers treatment possibility at home vs jail medical facility.
column9: Mentally ill accused: bail granted if home treatment possible. Jail = additional trauma.

column7: False rape claim prosecution: woman making false claim punishable under Sec 182 IPC.
column9: Woman making false rape claim? She can be prosecuted under Sec 182 IPC (false statement to police).

column7: Bail during trial: not to be used as punishment. If evidence weak bail continues. Final acquittal possible.
column9: Bail granted? Continue through trial. Weak evidence = likely acquittal. Bail NOT punishment.
